headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: GA Prosecutor Nathan Wade Questioned About Relationship With Fani Willis. Aired 11-11:30a ET

utterances.speaker: ASHLEIGH MERCHANT, DEFENSE ATTORNEY FOR MIKE ROMAN
utterances.sentences: It's supposed to be number. I guess they're all numbered one, so. Number one, number one again, and then the third number one.ANNA GREEN CROSS, ATTORNEY FOR FULTON COUNTY DA'S OFFICE: Haven't seen my five (inaudible) or something?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: He didn't put page numbers on it.(OFF-MIC)

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I don't know how to tell you what number one. Because when you responded, you put number one on all of them.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE SCOTT MCAFEE, FULTON COUNTY SUPERIOR COURT
utterances.sentences: Can you just point to it.NATHAN WADE, SPECIAL PROSECUTOR IN TRUMP'S GA ELECTION CASE: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: This one. This one, I'm talking about this number one, where it is tapped. There's two number ones that are tapped.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And the same page number, but it is the second page.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: They're asking if you have any receipts for restaurants, hotels, bars, things like that.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: The first number one?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I believe it's the second number one.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: The second number one. OK.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. So it asks you if you have any receipts for things like restaurants, bars, hotels, things like that, where you accompanied a member of the other sex romantic partner. Correct? WADE

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And so, (inaudible) it says to identify any and all occasions where you entertained a member of the other sex, OK, who's not related to blood and including dining, drinking, restaurants, bars, pubs, hotels, all of that. OK. And what was your answer to that?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: None.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: None. OK. So May 30th, 2023, you prepared this document?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Submitted it?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And it says none as far as entertaining a member of the opposite sex.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: It does.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. No hotels, no bars, no restaurants?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. You again updated that. Let's see. You updated it on December 22nd, 2023? And I'm going to mark that as defendant's number five, and I have copies. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And then you updated it once again on January 26th, 2024, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. It's that one. May I approach the witness again, judge?

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Is that what you're marking as defense exhibit six?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Yes, judge. I'm marking number six is the January 26th, 2024 interrogatory, and then one, so that one, and then number five is the December 22nd, 2023 interrogatory response.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Are you tendering those at this time?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Yes, I am.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Any objection from any council, defense exhibit five and six?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Yes. No objection.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Ms. Cross. Seeing none others. MERCHANT

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Mm-hmm.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And one of them was December 22nd, and then of this last year, so last December. And then one was just recently submitted in January, right?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Mm-hmm.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. In May 20, what, let's see, May 10th, 2023, Judge Thompson heard a motion to compel in your divorce case as well, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And you were actually held in a willful contempt?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to object to the relevance.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Ms. Merchant.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: His credibility is relevant, judge. And if he was held in willful contempt for failing to provide answers and documents, I think that's relevant to this court.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: How is that a prior false act or crime of conviction or anything else allowed for impeachment of the rules of evidence?

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: But just contempt generally can be for many different things, like a failure to produce is not necessarily a false act, right?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Right. And he's welcome to explain that.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: He may not have to. Ms. Cross?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I object to the relevance of that. That's clearly not a proper impeachment. We're going pretty far field into divorce matters that don't have any direct relevance to anything that's pending for the court. The court objected the relevance to that and need further --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Not seeing that being a proper grounds for impeachment. It's sustained.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. Let's talk about this, December 22nd, 2023 verification. I tabbed it for you. Again, they asked you if you had any documentations showing proof of this relationship, proof of any relationship, correct?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to object to the phrasing of that question. I don't believe that's an accurate read of the interrogatory.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Let's be precise, Ms. Merchant.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And you please read it. I want to make sure I'm accurate. Please read it.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Which number?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: This one actually has a number. I tabbed it for you, so you should be able to open right to the page. It's number 22. The question specifically is if you have any tangible evidence of any nature in your possession or control or any other person or entity which relates to any manner of your activities, to any person with whom you've had a sexual relationship during your marriage, tangible evidence is notes, cards, letters, photos, films, recordings, documents, tapes, video recordings, receipts, invoices, and other tangible evidence?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And you answered that you did not have any documents to that effect, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And that was on December 22nd, 2023?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You updated those responses again after the motion to disqualify was filed, though, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: When was the motion filed?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: January 8th, 2024, when I filed the motion to disqualify you and alleged that you had a romantic relationship with Ms. Willis?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: After that, you updated these responses, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And so your new responses, you now changed your answer from that you didn't have any of this to, you're asserting the privilege under 245505, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And both of these are under oath?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am. MERCHANT

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. So in December of 2023, you said no to all that, and then in January, after I filed my motion, you said privilege to all that, Fifth Amendment privilege?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And just to be clear, was it --

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry. I'm going to object. The characterization of Fifth Amendment privilege, I think it was a statutory privilege, and that's quite different.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: That's why I was just about to ask him. So that privilege covers infamy or Fifth Amendment privilege, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: So it was a privacy privilege is what I updated my response to do. Once you filed your motion to intervene in my divorce action, I then figured that you were in talks with my former wife's divorce lawyer.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: And because of that, I asserted a privacy privilege because I didn't want the proceedings of my divorce to bleed over into the proceedings in this case, which is the case that obviously you're involved in.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So your answer is in December of 2023, that you didn't have any documents about any travel that you took with Ms. Willis, that wasn't true, though, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: They didn't ask me about any documents regarding Ms. Willis.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: A romantic partner. They asked you for documents regarding a romantic partner. So I'm sorry I inserted Ms. Willis's name. Let me rephrase the question. They asked you for documents about travel with a romantic partner in December 2023. And you, under oath, said you did not have any of those, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I did not.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: And they asked me about gifts.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I never purchased a gift for Ms. Willis. MERCHANT

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I did not. And do not have any receipts for any of those things.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And part of the civil discovery, they say that even if you don't have it in your pocket, if it's within your purvey, you got to get it and give it to them, correct?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Your honor, I'm going to object again to the relevance of the questions about the scope of civil discovery. I think she's asking about statements he made in pleadings. The answers are already in the record. And --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. To the extent you're trying to establish a prior mistruth, Ms. Merchant, I'll allow you to ask a few more follow ups, but if it's not there, we have to move on.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: In that affidavit, you swore under oath, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And in that affidavit, you swore that, well, first of all, do you recognize the affidavit?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. Did you sign the affidavit under oath?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I did. MERCHANT

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Nobody forced you to sign this?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: No, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You chose to sign it?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And you signed it on purpose to admit into court to refute allegations?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You signed it specifically to prove that you were not in a relationship with Willis prior to November 2021, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And you were a lawyer when you signed it?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I was.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And you're still a lawyer today, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: When were you barred?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And you believe that your relationship with Ms. Willis is subject to attorney-client privilege, correct?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to object to that, your honor. I don't think that's factually correct. I don't think that's a relevant question, and I don't think it's appropriate to question this witness about the scope of his attorney-client privilege. He's got an attorney who can speak for him for that. But questioning the witness, I think, is inappropriate.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right, so a lot to unpack there. The question is simply that, does he believe there's a relationship that exists in terms of attorney client privilege between him and Ms. Willis? Is that accurate Ms. Merchant?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Yes, judge. It was. I asked if he believed his relationship with Ms. Willis is subject to attorney-client privilege.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: OK. I don't see why yes or no would be barred.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Maybe I'm not understanding the question. If the question is, does Mr. Wade and District Attorney Willis have an attorney-client relationship?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: It is not.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: There's no foundation for that. If the question to the witness is, does his relationship with District Attorney Willis impact his attorney-client relationship with his divorce attorneys, that I don't think is an appropriate question for that witness. First, I believe, is a proper phrasing. The second, I think there's been a representation that Mr. Wade preserves and doesn't waive anything. And so I think asking him particular questions in order to potentially backdoor a waiver is inappropriate, and that's my objection.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. If we're just trying to, again, assess where a privilege does or does not exist, and we're not actually getting into it, I think that we can establish those, you know, parameters. But Ms. Merchant, can you rephrase the question based on that concern and we'll see where we are?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Yes. Do you believe, you, that your relationship with Ms. Willis is subject to an attorney-client privilege? Not if you and Ms. Willis have one. But do you believe that relationship is subject to one?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to object to that question as it's phrased. In what context, any conversation with his attorneys is privilege, that I think is clear. What's not clear to me from that question is, is that, is Ms. Merchant asking in the context of your communication with your attorneys, is that or outside that context is it.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Right. And, Ms. Merchant, I think we need to figure out what are we getting at with this.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I'm just trying to figure out if he thought that their relationship is subject to an attorney-client privilege. I mean, it's been asserted. I think it's going to be asserted. And that was all I was asking.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: I mean the actions themselves wouldn't be an issue. It's more communication.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Someone saw them. Someone had knowledge of it. Is that attorney-client privilege? I want to know.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: In 2022, in this affidavit, you swore that you and Willis developed a personal relationship.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And you said that didn't develop until 2022, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And that's different from what you said in your pleading in May 2023 in the divorce case, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: No, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: In May 2023, when you were asked if. If you had a -- if you'd had any affairs, essentially, and you said none?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. So in May 2023 you said you had not -- in May 2023, in the divorce case, you said you had not had a personal relationship, an affair, a romantic relationship with anyone?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: But you told this court in the affidavit that you did have one that started in 2022, so that would have been ongoing at 2023.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: So here, I think there's a distinction, if you'd allow me to explain.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Please.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: The interrogatory asks the question during the course of your marriage --

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Or to date, it actually says --

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to request that the witness be permitted to answer.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Wade?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: So my marriage was irretrievably broken in 2015, ma'am, by agreement. My wife and I agreed that once she had the affair in 2015, that we'd get a divorce. We didn't get a divorce immediately because my children were still in school, and I refused to allow them to grow up without their father at the time. So we waited. We waited until the youngest graduated, and we dropped her off at college and didn't file for the divorce. So if you're asking me about the interrogatory as it relates to having the 2022 relationship with District Attorney Willis, I'm going to say because my marriage was irretrievably broken, I was free to have a relationship.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So the question, though, was if you had a relationship, and in 2023, you said you did not. And that is different than what you said in this affidavit, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: No, ma'am. I said during the course of my marriage. So 2023 --

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And you believe it too.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Let them finish, Ms. Merchant.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: So in 2015, my marriage was irretrievably broken. So I did not have a relationship with anyone during the course of my marriage.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And in that interrogatory, they asked you if you had any receipts for travel with someone of the other sex up until the time you were answering it. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And you said that you didn't. You've already testified to that earlier, but in this affidavit, you said you swore that you had travel expenses and shared expenses on travel with Ms. Willis?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Again, during the course of my marriage, I had no relationship or receipts.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I'm not asking about during the course of your marriage.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: You honor, I'm going to ask the witness to be allowed to answer the question.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Continue. I have no problem with him answering.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: OK. As it relates to receipts today, I don't have any receipts, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So you don't have any travel receipts available to you for any travel that you did with Ms. Willis?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I don't have any receipts, no, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: No receipts that -- so your -- you used your business credit card for these trips, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I used my business credit card for everything.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. Yes. You used it for your kids tuition?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Used it for personal travel with Ms. Willis.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And you have receipts from those business credit cards that you have to file with your taxes, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: No, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I file this statement, I turn over the statement, and whatever is there on the statement, the accountant looks at it and the accountant says, OK, this is personal, goes over here. This is business, goes over here. Here are your taxes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So you have those statements? We'll call them statements instead of receipts. You have those statements, correct? WADE

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. But when you answered the interrogatory under oath, you said you did not have anything to show the record of travel with Ms. Willis.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I answered the question. I had no receipts, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You had no receipts, but you had statements.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I ordered the statement. Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You did order the statement. OK.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And so we're just talking the semantics between invoice and statements or receipt, I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to object, your honor, to the argumentative tone of the question. I believe it's an ask and answer --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right, sustain.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: In let's see. You also in this affidavit said that no funds paid to you for compensation as your role as special counsel was shared with Willis, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And that you never cohabitated with Willis, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: By cohabitation, does that mean that you never spent the night with Willis?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And so when -- so I just want to qualify your term, your use of the term cohabitation, that means you didn't live together?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: But you did spend the night together?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: When was the first time you spent the night together?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Your honor --

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: that's the subject of his affidavit, judge. MCAFEE

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And I don't intend to do that, judge. But I think what is relevant is when the relationship started. And that's what you had indicated on --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Why don't we start with that question and go from there?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And that's what I asked when the first time he spent the night with her was boss. That's --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: That's a different question, isn't it?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. So let's not talk about when you spent the night. When did your romantic relationship with Ms. Willis begin?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: When in 2022?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Early 2022.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So you were appointed in November of 2021?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And your relationship started early. What's early? January, February?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Around March.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Around March. But you two met at an October 2019 judicial conference, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And describe your relationship at that point, then.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Which point?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: So I was at a judicial conference to teach a course, if you will, to newer judges. I did that in 2019. As I was exiting the conference, another judge was standing outside who was a friend of mine. I stopped and exchanged pleasantries with her. And standing, talking to her at the time was then Judge Willis. She introduced us at that time. We shook hands, exchanged business cards, and I got into my vehicle and left the conference. So that meeting was probably three minutes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. When was the next time you talked to her?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Didn't talk to her again, probably maybe a month or a month and a half had gone by.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. So you talked to her November maybe?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Maybe.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: On the phone?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: On the phone.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. How regularly did you speak with her in 2021 on the phone?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, 2019, I'm so sorry. 2019, how frequently did you speak with her on the phone?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: 2019, after the meeting, I probably talked to her two or three times. She would have questions. I was the district rep for the particular district that I sat in.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: And the judges would, when they would have questions, they sometimes would go to the rep. So she was outside of my district, but she would call me. She felt comfortable calling me to ask me the questions. I don't know if you know the racial makeup of certain benches, but it wasn't very diverse. So she felt comfortable calling me for advice, and she did that. And we had also in common that she was starting a private law practice at the time, and I'd already had mine up and going. And we talked about balancing the demands of the bench with their private practice. So we didn't talk that often.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: But when she had questions, mostly legal issues that would come up, she would call me.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I just want to make sure, because my question was just how many times? And you said two to three times, right?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. And in 2022, how frequently did you speak in 2022? This is before you were appointed.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, Ms. Merchant's, your timeline, 2022?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry 2020. 2020, how frequently did you speak in 2020?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: 2020, it was more frequent than '19, obviously, but.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: More frequent, can you tell me, approximately a month, how often you think you spoke with her on the phone?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to object to the granular detail. I think Mr. Wade can certainly answer however he wants to. But if we're going to go through every time they spoke on the phone, as opposed to generally characterizing the relationship, it would be more detailed if necessary.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Judge, I'm not going to go through every time they spoke on the phone. I'm asking for generally how frequently they spoke.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you. About how frequently did you speak in 2020?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Per month?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I mean, if it was two or three times that entire year, you can tell me that. If it was more than that, then you can quantify it by month.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: No, no. We spoke on the telephone often. I mean, I don't know how many -- I couldn't give you an amount of time because you remember COVID happened, and the world was shut down on but, so we spoke on the phone more than 2019, definitely.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. Let's qualify it. Before her election in 2020, how much -- how frequently did you speak?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: You mean as she was campaigning?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Before the election? Before, yes, as she was campaigning before she was elected.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: It's two different animals.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: As she was campaigning before she was elected.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: OK. So during the course of her campaign, we didn't talk as much, obviously, because she was busy. Fulton County is a large jurisdiction to cover. But we didn't talk whole lot. But she did know that I had gone through the election process, so when things would come up, and she had questions about, she would call me and ask me, so.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And just to be fair, I'm only --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Ms. Merchant.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Judge, actually, he's not asked and answered. And, I mean, I don't mind him explaining, but I just wanted to know how many times. I mean, if we talk about every conversation they talked about I --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: You got to let him finish his sentence. And then if you need to redirect him or have me direct him, I can. Mr. Wade, you can continue.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir. So sometimes it would be like a three second call. She would go, during your election, have you ever seen this? And I would say, no, but here's what I would do, and we'd hang up. She had a lot of professionals working for her, but she trusted my judgment. So she called me, and it'd, you know, be brief conversation, but she called.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So my question was, how frequently did you speak with her prior to her election? Frequently, infrequently?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: More than 2019, but it wasn't an everyday thing. No.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. In 2021, before you were appointed in November, so January to November, 2021, the only time I'm talking about, how frequently did you speak with Ms. Willis on the phone?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: In 2021, then it became frequent.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Frequent?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. But you did not work at the DA's office at that point, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I did not.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So the affidavit that you submitted, you showed on it, you submitted one record that showed that Ms. Willis had paid a couple hundred dollars for one flight, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Say again?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: The affidavit that you submitted to this court showed that Ms. Willis had paid for one flight, several hundred dollars. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: No, ma'am. I think that are you drawing a distinction for her paying for a flight or for her actually booking a flight, because those are two separate things.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I will re ask it.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: The affidavit you filed in this court, you alleged that Ms. Willis paid for one flight. Paid for one flight, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: No, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You did not allege she paid for one flight?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: No, ma'am. What I allege is that our travel was split roughly, evenly. So where you see, I have booked a flight or I've paid for a flight with my credit card, what you don't see is that she covered her own flight reimbursement to me. The flights that you see here are the flights that she would have booked with her own resources, with her own card.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And there's one flight, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: One flight reflecting that she actually booked with --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Ms. Merchant, let him finish and then you can redirect him.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: One flight that she actually booked? Yes. The other flights I booked, she paid for.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So the affidavit, you submitted one flight that she booked and paid for?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Understand Ms. Cross I think that's something you can, it's now on the record, but also something you can take on cross.
